options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: n/a
A hybrid of lecture and learning seminar (repeat after the teacher and form our own sentences)

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned the basics of Chinese grammar, tones, and vocabulary. Language courses are always the best for actually seeing your progress with your learning, and you definitely can see your progress in this class.
Introduction to the Chinese Language.
elementary introduction to the Chinese reading, speaking, and writing.
I learned Chinese vocabulary and grammar and developed writing and reading skills
I developed a skill of reading, writing, and speaking Chinese,
Fundamental skills of Chinese
I learned the basics of Chinese. I learned how to read, write, and speak Mandarin.
Beginning Chinese - basic vocabs and grammar

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: There wasn't too much speaking/interpersonal practice, but that can be expected from an L1 course. Overall, I think it teaches the basics well. There isn't a huge focus on actually learning the characters per se, but I think a part of that is due to the online format.

The biggest weakness is the speed at which this course moves. For an actual beginner in the language it requires hours and hours of time outside of class just to try and get caught up. Each lesson was rushed through, thus by the the time you complete the next lesson, you already forget the one before it. This course moves too quick for an actual beginner to master the concepts being taught.

One of the strengths is that due to the very high engagement levels of the course, I get a very good grasp of the language. However the workload is quite heavy because we have homework that is due everyday.
Really good at drilling reading and writing skills, but sentence structures were not reviewed often.

The strength was that it was highly interactive.
The weakness was that there were some lags on Zoom.
Curriculum and syllabus were very clear

The biggest weakness for me was in terms of logistics: we would check the "weekly schedule" to see what assignments we have to do and the plan for this week. Instead of concentrating everything on Canvas, we would have to go to Quia and do workbook exercises too. I feel like it could easily be organised in a more straight-forward way. This also impacts the final grade. It is kinda difficult to understand what went into the evaluation.

Strength - very engaging professor, daily homework to keep you in check, and very good TAs and resources
Weakness - A LOT of daily homework and quizzes and can get overwhelming at times. Also, you don't really know your final grade until the end of the term.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: We were given Wednesdays off to just have individual sessions with the professor instead of having class. I think that allows for us to breathe a little to cope with the zoom fatigue.
I believe that the individual sessions were helpful.
The biggest impact virtual learning had is shifting to writing on a computer instead of on paper. This effectively means much less pressure to learn how to write the characters properly.
The demanding workload of Chinese makes it hard to maintain interest/excitement of learning a new language during a pandemic.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would definitely recommend this course! Chinese may seem daunting from an English speaker's point of view, but the class is taught well and doesn't feel overwhelming. The class culture is great too.
I would not recommend this unless you are extremely passionate about learning the chinese language.
I would definitely recommend this course for any student who is interested in learning Chinese! I learned a surprising amount in just a few months and can already recognize many characters.
Yes if you want a strong grasp of the language.
Absolutely. Professor Shen was excellent at teaching students and helping us understand the subject.
Yes, this course is intensive and would allow for a deep understanding of the Chinese language and culture.
If you want to learn Chinese, go for it!
Yes, if you are interested in learning Chinese. Chinese is an excellent department, but expect 2-3 hours of homework every day.
